AlertDefinition.description: Virtual machine disk I/O write latency is high
AlertDefinition.name: Virtual machine disk I/O write latency is high

AlertDefinition.description: This vSphere distributed virtual switch is violating one or more guidelines in VMware vSphere Security Configuration Guide
AlertDefinition.name: vSphere Distributed Virtual Switch is violating VMware vSphere Security Configuration Guide

AlertDefinition.description: Virtual machine is running applications that are unexpectedly using significant amount of disk I/O
AlertDefinition.name: Virtual machine has unexpected high disk I/O workload

AlertDefinition.description: The Distributed Switch configuration for the host(s) indicated in the issue details is incorrect. A single NIC on the host is connected to the Distributed Switch
AlertDefinition.name: The Distributed Switch configuration is incorrect

AlertDefinition.description: The fault tolerance state of a virtual machine changed from an expected or good state to a "Disabled" state. If the virtual machine is the primary in a fault tolerant group, this state indicates that the virtual machine has at least one registered secondary, but no secondary is enabled. If the virtual machine is the secondary in a fault tolerant group, this state indicates that the secondary is disabled.
AlertDefinition.name: The Fault tolerance state of the virtual machine has changed to a "Disabled" state

AlertDefinition.description: This vSphere distributed port group is violating one or more guidelines in VMware vSphere Security Configuration Guide
AlertDefinition.name: vSphere Distributed Port Group is violating VMware vSphere Security Configuration Guide

AlertDefinition.description: Host in a cluster that does not have fully-automated DRS enabled has memory contention caused by overpopulation of virtual machines. More than half of the virtual machines are overloading the host
AlertDefinition.name: Host in a cluster that does not have fully-automated DRS enabled has memory contention caused by more than half of the virtual machines

AlertDefinition.description: Virtual machine has memory contention due to memory compression, ballooning, or swapping. This is usually caused by overpopulation of virtual machines on the host
AlertDefinition.name: Virtual machine has memory contention due to memory compression, ballooning, or swapping

AlertDefinition.description: A recoverable Peripheral Component Interconnect Express (PCIe) error was detected when the system was previously booted. This error is typically caused by a faulty PCIe bus and might cause unstable system behavior, but the error is recoverable. The device, bus number, vendor name etc should appear in the fault description.
AlertDefinition.name: A PCIe error occurred during system boot, but the error is recoverable

AlertDefinition.description: One or more memory sensors on the host are reporting problems. Specific details should be available in the symptom details. For more information, check the Hardware Status of the host in vSphere Client.
AlertDefinition.name: Memory sensors are reporting problems

AlertDefinition.description:
Virtual machine will have an invalid state if the VM configuration format is invalid. The configuration is accessible on disk, but corrupted in a way that does not allow the vCenter Server to read the content.
Virtual machine will have an orphaned state if it is no longer registered on the host it is associated with. A VM that is unregistered or deleted directly on a host managed by vCenter Server shows up in this state.
Virtual machines can become invalid or orphaned under various conditions: - after a High Availability (HA) host failover is unsuccessful - after a host comes out of maintenance mode - after a failed DRS migration - after a storage failure - after the connection is lost between the vCenter Server and the host where the virtual machine resides
AlertDefinition.name: Virtual machine is in an invalid or orphaned state

AlertDefinition.description: VMware Vsphere Security Configuration Guide's Risk profile 1 provides guidelines that should be implemented in highest security environments. This virtual machine is violating one or more guidelines.
AlertDefinition.name: Virtual Machine is violating Risk Profile 1 in VMware vSphere Security Configuration Guide

AlertDefinition.description: One or more portgroups in the host lost connectivity to the dvPort. As a result, the services associated with the affected dvPorts are disconnected from the associated physical networks. All physical connections to the dvPort from the associated switch will become unavailable.
AlertDefinition.name: The host has lost connectivity to a dvPort

AlertDefinition.description: A cluster with DRS enabled and set to fully-automated has memory contention caused by overpopulation of virtual machines. No particular virtual machine is causing the problem but collectively they are overloading the cluster
AlertDefinition.name: Fully-automated DRS-enabled cluster has memory contention caused by overpopulation of virtual machines

AlertDefinition.description:
Datastore has hosts that have lost all of the redundant paths to a storage device and only one active path remains. The symptom details contains the hosts, storage devices, and paths affected by this fault. The ESX host and virtual machines can still access the storage device through the remaining active path, but connectivity will be lost if the last active path is lost.
NOTE: For vSphere versions earlier than 5.0, this fault might indicate a permanent loss of the storage device. If you expect the storage device to be permanently lost because of an upgrades or decommissioning of storage, you must manually cancel the alert.
AlertDefinition.name: Datastore has one or more hosts that have lost redundant paths to a storage device

AlertDefinition.description: Host that is not in a cluster has CPU contention caused by overpopulation of virtual machines. No particular virtual machine is causing the problem but collectively they are overloading the host
AlertDefinition.name: Standalone host has CPU contention caused by overpopulation of virtual machines

AlertDefinition.description: One or more ports on the Distributed Port Group are experiencing network contention due to dropped packets
AlertDefinition.name: One or more ports are experiencing network contention

AlertDefinition.description:
When a physical NIC experiences frequent link status flapping, ESXi might turn off the physical NIC to avoid unnecessary link failover and network instability. For example, a physical NIC driver might reset the physical NIC when it detects "tx Hang". A reset causes a link down or up event to be generated. If the physical NIC is faulty, this problem causes periodic reset and link status flapping.
During link status flapping, traffic might migrate between different physical NICs. If the flapping is too frequent, network problems occur, such as bandwidth reduction or an unstable network.
AlertDefinition.name: ESXi host has detected a link status "flapping" on a physical NIC

AlertDefinition.description: Data collection from the vCenter Server instance is taking longer than 5 minutes, and might be caused by one of the following reasons: - The vCenter Server instance is experiencing performance problems, which is causing a slow response to the vCenter adapter. - The vCenter adapter is connecting to the vCenter Server instance over a high latency network.
AlertDefinition.name: vCenter data collection is slow

AlertDefinition.description: One or more storage sensors on the host are reporting problems. Specific details should be available in the symptom details. For more information, check the Hardware Status of the host in vSphere Client.
AlertDefinition.name: Storage sensors are reporting problems

AlertDefinition.description: One or more power sensors on the host are reporting problems. Specific details should be available in the symptom details. For more information, check the Hardware Status of the host in vSphere Client.
AlertDefinition.name: Power sensors are reporting problems

AlertDefinition.description: The host lost connectivity to one or more NFS servers. The NFS volumes and the virtual machines on the affected volumes might be unavailable to the server. This fault typically occurs in an environment where NFS was previously working and NFS connectivity was lost.
AlertDefinition.name: The host lost connectivity to a Network File System (NFS) server

AlertDefinition.description: A cluster with DRS enabled and set to fully-automated has high memory workload and contention
AlertDefinition.name: Fully-automated DRS-enabled cluster has high memory workload and contention

AlertDefinition.description: vSphere HA is unable to start the virtual machine after it is powered off in response to a network isolation event on the host. This is because it cannot persist the necessary metadata to the datastore since the datastore has become inaccessible immediately after vSphere HA powered off the virtual machine.
AlertDefinition.name: vSphere HA failed to restart a network isolated virtual machine

AlertDefinition.description: A fatal error was detected on a Peripheral Component Interconnect Express (PCIe) bus during the previous reboot. Typically, this problem is caused by faulty hardware. The bus is faulty and might cause unstable system behavior. The device, bus number, vendor name, and other device-related information should appear in the symptom details.
AlertDefinition.name: A fatal error ocurred on a PCIe bus during system reboot

AlertDefinition.description: One or more VLANs on the host are unsupported by the physical switch
AlertDefinition.name: One or more VLANs are unsupported by the physical switch

AlertDefinition.description: One or more fan sensors on the host are reporting problems. Specific details should be available in the symptom details. For more information, check the Hardware Status of the host in vSphere Client.
AlertDefinition.name: Fan sensors are reporting problems

AlertDefinition.description: One or more ports on this port group are in a link down state
AlertDefinition.name: One or more ports are in a link down state

AlertDefinition.description:
vSphere HA has detected that the host is network-isolated and has powered off or shut down virtual machines running on the host. A host is network isolated if both of the following conditions are met: - Isolation addresses are configured and the host is unable to ping the addresses. - The vSphere HA agent on the host cannot access any of the agents that are running on the other cluster hosts.
When a host is network-isolated, it continues to monitor the virtual machines that remain powered-on. Host network isolation affects how vSphere HA restarts virtual machines after a failure. vSphere HA powers off or shuts down a virtual machine only if the agent on the host determines that a master host is responsible for the virtual machine.
AlertDefinition.name: vSphere High Availability (HA) has detected a network-isolated host

AlertDefinition.description: Host in a cluster that does not have fully-automated DRS enabled has memory contention caused by overpopulation of virtual machines. No particular virtual machine is causing the problem but collectively they are overloading the host
AlertDefinition.name: Host in a cluster that does not have fully-automated DRS enabled has memory contention caused by overpopulation of virtual machines

AlertDefinition.description: The host has been unexpectedly disconnected from vCenter Server. The virtual machines on the host have also lost connectivity to vCenter Server. The host might not have a problem and the virtual machines on the host might be running as expected, but any configuration, data, and events from the host and its virtual machines are lost.
AlertDefinition.name: Host has lost connection to vCenter Server

AlertDefinition.description: Host in a cluster that does not have fully-automated DRS enabled has CPU contention caused by overpopulation of virtual machines. No particular virtual machine is causing the problem but collectively they are overloading the host
AlertDefinition.name: Host in a cluster that does not have fully-automated DRS enabled has CPU contention caused by overpopulation of virtual machines

AlertDefinition.description: Virtual machine is demanding more CPU than its entitlement
AlertDefinition.name: Virtual machine is demanding more CPU than its entitlement

AlertDefinition.description: This ESXi host is violating one or more guidelines in VMware vSphere Security Configuration Guide.
AlertDefinition.name: ESXi Host is violating VMware vSphere Security Configuration Guide

AlertDefinition.description: A vSphere HA master agent considers a host to have failed if it loses contact with the vSphere HA agent on the host, the host does not respond to pings on any of the management interfaces, and the master does not observe any datastore heartbeats. This problem can occur when a computer on the network is configured to have the same IP address as one of the ESX/ESXi hosts in a HA cluster. In this situation, the HA agent receives invalid data and generates errors. The HA agent does not function properly until it is reconfigured. The frequency of this problem depends on how often the IP address conflict occurs.
AlertDefinition.name: vSphere High Availability (HA) has detected a possible host failure

AlertDefinition.description: One or more temperature sensors on the host are reporting problems. Specific details should be available in the symptom details. For more information, check the Hardware Status of the host in vSphere Client.
AlertDefinition.name: Temperature sensors are reporting problems

AlertDefinition.description: One or more port groups in the host have lost the last redundant uplink to the physical network. Port groups are still connected, but have only one remaining uplink. The current working uplink is a single point of failure for the reported port groups and might cause virtual machines, the service console, vMotion, NFS, iSCSI, and Management Services to become unavailable. Because your ESX host is now working with a single point of failure at the networking layer, you should fix this problem as soon as possible.
AlertDefinition.name: The host has lost redundant uplinks to the network

AlertDefinition.description: One or more Baseboard Management Controller sensors on the host are reporting problems. Specific details should be available in the symptom details. For more information, check the Hardware Status of the host in vSphere Client.
AlertDefinition.name: Baseboard Management Controller sensors are reporting problems

AlertDefinition.description: Host that is not in a cluster has memory contention caused by overpopulation of virtual machines. More than half of the virtual machines are overloading the host
AlertDefinition.name: Standalone host has memory contention caused by more than half of the virtual machines

AlertDefinition.description:
Connectivity has been lost to the specified storage device. The symptom details contains the hosts, storage devices, and paths that are affected by the fault. The path indicated for a host or device is the last path that went down. virtual machines that use the affected datastore might become unresponsive. If the service console root file system is on the affected datastore, the service console is unresponsive and you cannot manage the ESX host.
NOTE: For vSphere versions earlier than 5.0, this fault might indicate a permanent loss of the storage device. If you expect the storage device to be permanently lost because of an upgrades or decommissioning of storage, you must manually cancel the fault. The alert will be canceled automatically after that.
AlertDefinition.name: Datastore has lost connectivity to a storage device

AlertDefinition.description:
A host is reported as network-partitioned if both the following conditions are met: - The vSphere HA master host to which vCenter Server is connected is unable to communicate with the host by using the management network, but is able to communicate with that host by using the heartbeat datastores that have been selected for it. - The host is not isolated. A network partition can occur for a number of reasons including incorrect VLAN tagging, the failure of a physical NIC or switch, configuring a cluster with some hosts that use only IPv4 and others that use only IPv6, or the management networks for some hosts were moved to a different virtual switch without first putting the host into maintenance mode.
While the virtual machines running on the host continue to be monitored by the master hosts that are responsible for them, vSphere HA's ability to restart the virtual machines after a failure is affected. Further, each master host has access to a subset of the hosts, so less failover capacity is available to each host.
AlertDefinition.name: vSphere High Availability (HA) has detected a network-partitioned host

AlertDefinition.description: Host that is not in a cluster has CPU contention caused by overpopulation of virtual machines. More than half of the virtual machines are overloading the host
AlertDefinition.name: Standalone host has CPU contention caused by more than half of the virtual machines

AlertDefinition.description: The MTU on the Distributed Switch is not allowed by one or more VLANs on the host
AlertDefinition.name: The MTU on the Distributed Switch is not allowed by one or more VLANs on the host

AlertDefinition.description: The teaming configuration on the host does not match the physical switch
AlertDefinition.name: Teaming configuration does not match the physical switch

AlertDefinition.description: One or more processor sensors on the host are reporting problems. Specific details should be available in the symptom details. For more information, check the Hardware Status of the host in vSphere Client.
AlertDefinition.name: Processor sensors are reporting problems

AlertDefinition.description:
A virtual machine cannot be powered back on because the cluster does not have sufficient CPU or memory resources to meet the requirements of the virtual machine.
vSphere HA generates this alert condition when the master is unable to fail over a virtual machine because it cannot find a host that has enough resources to satisfy the CPU reservation and the sum of the memory reservation and overhead.
Typically, this condition occurs if vSphere HA admission control is disabled or if the number of hosts that fail is great than the number of provisioned hosts. The condition can also occur if the available resources are not usable by a virtual machine because of fragmentation, or the virtual machine is unable to run on hosts that have available capacity. If DRS is enabled, this event triggers a DRS action to defragment the cluster or bring hosts out of Standby Mode.
AlertDefinition.name: Not enough resources for vSphere HA to start the virtual machine

AlertDefinition.description: One or more system board sensors on the host are reporting problems. Specific details should be available in the symptom details. For more information, check the Hardware Status of the host in vSphere Client.
AlertDefinition.name: System Board sensors are reporting problems

AlertDefinition.description: Virtual machine is experiencing high co-stop. Co-stop represents the amount of time that a virtual machine is ready to run, but is experiencing delay because of co-vCPU scheduling contention. High Co-stop occurs when too many vCPUs are configured for the virtual machine, and not enough physical CPUs are available to manage the co-vCPU scheduling
AlertDefinition.name: Virtual machine has CPU contention due to multi-vCPU scheduling issues (co-stop) caused by too many vCPUs

AlertDefinition.description:
The HA agent on the host can go into an error state for a number of reasons, such as: - Agent is unreachable by the master host - Agent could not be initialized and configured for vSphere HA correctly - Agent is unable to listen on its TCP port - Agent lost access to the datastores - Agent could not open the firewall ports
The symptoms should indicate the specific error.
AlertDefinition.name: vSphere High Availability (HA) host agent has encountered an error

AlertDefinition.description: Virtual machine is experiencing high swap wait. Swap wait represents the amount of time that a virtual machine is waiting while the host is swapping in memory pages. The host is overcommitted on memory and has resorted to swapping, which is degrading the performance of the virtual machine
AlertDefinition.name: Virtual machine has CPU contention due to memory page swapping in the host

AlertDefinition.description: Host that is not in a cluster has CPU contention. Half or fewer of the virtual machines are overloading the host
AlertDefinition.name: Standalone host has CPU contention caused by less than half of the virtual machines

AlertDefinition.description: The Distributed Switch configuration on the host is out of sync with vCenter
AlertDefinition.name: Distributed Switch configuration is out of sync

AlertDefinition.description: Host has no port groups enabled for vSphere HA communication. The following are the networking requirements for a vSphere HA cluster: - All hosts must be configured with static IP addresses. If you are using DHCP, you must ensure that the address for each host persists across reboots. - All hosts must have at least one management network in common. The best practice is to have at least two management networks in common. You should use the VMkernel network with the Management traffic checkbox enabled. The networks must be accessible to each other and vCenter Server and the hosts must be accessible to each other on the management networks
AlertDefinition.name: Host has no port groups enabled for vSphere HA communication

AlertDefinition.description: A cluster with DRS enabled and set to fully-automated has CPU contention caused by overpopulation of virtual machines. More than half of the virtual machines are overloading the cluster
AlertDefinition.name: Fully-automated DRS-enabled cluster has CPU contention caused by more than half of the virtual machines

AlertDefinition.description: Virtual machine in a cluster is demanding more CPU than its entitlement
AlertDefinition.name: Virtual machine in a cluster is demanding more CPU than its entitlement

AlertDefinition.description: This vCenter is violating one or more guidelines in VMware vSphere Security Configuration Guide.
AlertDefinition.name: vCenter is violating VMware vSphere Security Configuration Guide

AlertDefinition.description: A cluster with DRS enabled and set to fully-automated has CPU contention. Half or fewer of the virtual machines are overloading the cluster
AlertDefinition.name: Fully-automated DRS-enabled cluster has CPU contention caused by less than half of the virtual machines

AlertDefinition.description: A cluster with DRS enabled and set to fully-automated has high CPU workload
AlertDefinition.name: Fully-automated DRS-enabled cluster has high CPU workload

AlertDefinition.description: Host in a cluster that does not have fully-automated DRS enabled has CPU contention caused by overpopulation of virtual machines. More than half of the virtual machines are overloading the host
AlertDefinition.name: Host in a cluster that does not have fully-automated DRS enabled has CPU contention caused by more than half of the virtual machines

AlertDefinition.description: Host that is not in a cluster has memory contention. Half or fewer of the virtual machines are overloading the host
AlertDefinition.name: Standalone host has memory contention caused by less than half of the virtual machines

AlertDefinition.description: Host is experiencing network contention caused by too much traffic from all the virtual machines
AlertDefinition.name: Host is experiencing network contention caused by too much traffic

AlertDefinition.description: Host that is not in a clusterhas memory contention caused by overpopulation of virtual machines. No particular virtual machine is causing problem but collectively they are overloading the host
AlertDefinition.name: Standalone host has memory contention caused by overpopulation of virtual machines

AlertDefinition.description: An error was detected in the system memory when the system was previously booted. This error is typically caused by faulty memory hardware, but is recoverable. The card or module and other memory device information should appear in the symptom details.
AlertDefinition.name: A recoverable memory error has occurred on the host

AlertDefinition.description: Virtual machine is running an unsupported version of VMware Tools. It is unsupported for one the following reasons: - It is too old. - It is too new to work correctly with this virtual machine. - It contains a serious issue and should be immediately upgraded.
AlertDefinition.name: Virtual machine has unsupported VMware Tools

AlertDefinition.description: The turned off SCSI devices are unavailable to the hosts and virtual machines to which they are connected.
AlertDefinition.name: A storage device for a datastore has been detected to be off

AlertDefinition.description: IPMI System Event Log for the host is becoming full. Specific details should be available in the symptom details. For more information, check the Hardware Status of the host in vSphere Client.
AlertDefinition.name: IPMI System Event Log for the host is becoming full

AlertDefinition.description: vSphere HA master missing
AlertDefinition.name: vSphere HA master missing

AlertDefinition.description: Virtual machine has a limit set on the memory consumption, but is demanding memory beyond the limit. This demand is leading to memory compression, ballooning, or swapping, which is adversely affecting the performance of the virtual machine
AlertDefinition.name: Virtual machine is experiencing memory compression, ballooning, or swapping due to memory limit

AlertDefinition.description:
Virtual machine is experiencing high co-stop due to the presence of snapshots. Co-stop represents the amount of time that a virtual machine is ready to run, but is experiencing delay because of co-vCPU scheduling contention.
Snapshots introduce complexity to storage I/O. Due to the nature of snapshots, every read operation must traverse every snapshot disk and then the base disk to verify the appropriate disk block to return. Because these extended read operations are required, snapshots are the most performance-intensive disk format for virtual disks (as opposed to thin-provisioned, thick-provisioned, or eager-zeroed thick-provisioned virtual disks).
As storage I/O for snapshots grows, co-stop values can increase because the vCPUs must wait for I/O completion
AlertDefinition.name: Virtual machine has CPU contention due to multi-vCPU scheduling issues (co-stop) caused by snapshots

AlertDefinition.description: Datastore is consuming disk space as expected, but will soon run out of space
AlertDefinition.name: Datastore is running out of disk space

AlertDefinition.description: CPU or memory workload is spread unevenly among the hosts in the cluster
AlertDefinition.name: Cluster has unbalanced workload

AlertDefinition.description: Virtual machine disk I/O read latency is high
AlertDefinition.name: Virtual machine disk I/O read latency is high

AlertDefinition.description: Network traffic is blocked for one or more ports on the vSphere Distributed Switch
AlertDefinition.name: Network traffic is blocked for one or more ports

AlertDefinition.description: One or more portgroups in the host have lost connectivity to the network and all physical connections to the network from this switch are unavailable. Services that are associated with the affected portgroups, including virtual machines, the service console, vMotion, NFS, iSCSI, and Management Services, are disconnected from the associated physical networks.
AlertDefinition.name: The host has lost connectivity to physical network

AlertDefinition.description: Virtual machine in a DRS cluster is demanding more CPU than its entitlement
AlertDefinition.name: Virtual machine in a DRS cluster is demanding more CPU than its entitlement

AlertDefinition.description: Host is in maintenance mode for at least 72 hours. This might indicate that the maintenance task is taking longer to complete or the host was not taken out of maintenance mode due to oversight
AlertDefinition.name: Host is in maintenance mode for at least 72 hours

AlertDefinition.description: Virtual machine has disk I/O latency problem caused by snapshots
AlertDefinition.name: Virtual machine has disk I/O latency problem caused by snapshots

AlertDefinition.description: Host in a cluster that does not have fully-automated DRS enabled has CPU contention. Half or fewer of the virtual machines are overloading the host
AlertDefinition.name: Host in a cluster that does not have fully-automated DRS enabled has CPU contention caused by less than half of the virtual machines

AlertDefinition.description: A cluster with DRS enabled and set to fully-automated has CPU contention caused by overpopulation of virtual machines. No particular virtual machine is causing the problem but collectively they are overloading the cluster
AlertDefinition.name: Fully-automated DRS-enabled cluster has CPU contention caused by overpopulation of virtual machines

AlertDefinition.description: Virtual machine is demanding more CPU than the configured limit, indicating that it is undersized
AlertDefinition.name: Virtual machine is demanding more CPU than the configured limit

AlertDefinition.description: Host is experiencing high number of transmitted packets dropped
AlertDefinition.name: Host is experiencing high number of transmitted packets dropped

AlertDefinition.description: Host is experiencing high number of received packets dropped
AlertDefinition.name: Host is experiencing high number of received packets dropped

AlertDefinition.description: One or more voltage sensors on the host are reporting problems. Specific details should be available in the symptom details. For more information, check the Hardware Status of the host in vSphere Client.
AlertDefinition.name: Voltage sensors are reporting problems

AlertDefinition.description: The fault tolerance state of a virtual machine changed from an expected or good state to a "Needs Secondary" state. This problem occurs when the HA (FDM) is disabled in vCenter Server 5.0 on a cluster that contains Fault Tolerance pairs, and the primary virtual machine becomes unprotected without warning.
AlertDefinition.name: The Fault tolerance state of the virtual machine has changed to "Needs Secondary" state

AlertDefinition.description: One or more portgroups in the host have lost the last redundant connectivity to the dvPort. The current working connection is a single point of failure for the reported port groups and might cause the services associated with the affected port groups to become unavailable.
AlertDefinition.name: The host has lost redundant connectivity to a dvPort

AlertDefinition.description: There is an MTU mismatch between the host and the physical switch
AlertDefinition.name: There is an MTU mismatch between the host and a physical switch

AlertDefinition.description: vCenter Health Service detected problems with one or more of vCenter components. Check the symptom details for specific information.
AlertDefinition.name: A problem occurred with a vCenter component

AlertDefinition.description: An error was detected in the system memory when the system was previously booted. Typically, this error is caused by faulty memory hardware. Card or module and other memory device information should appear in the symptom details.
AlertDefinition.name: A fatal memory error was detected at system boot time

AlertDefinition.description:
Virtual machine is experiencing high I/O wait. I/O wait represents the amount of time that a virtual machine is waiting for completion of I/O events. Disk and network I/O operations are common causes of I/O wait because they are the slowest operations in the system.
High I/O wait can be due to a poorly performing storage device on which the virtual machine resides. A device in the virtual machine configuration that stops functioning or responding can also trigger high I/O wait. These devices can include but are not limited to serial pass-through, parallel pass-through and USB devices. For example, high I/O wait can occur when an ISO file that is left mounted in the virtual machine is accidentally deleted or moved to an alternate location
AlertDefinition.name: Virtual machine has CPU contention due to long wait for I/O events

AlertDefinition.description:
The cluster does not have sufficient unreserved capacity to satisfy the level that is configured for vSphere HA admission control. vSphere HA might still perform failovers, but only on a best-effort basis.
If the number of host failures to tolerate policy is configured, and a few virtual machines have a much higher CPU or memory reservation than other virtual machines, vSphere HA admission control can be excessively conservative to ensure that enough unfragmented resources exist if a host fails.
AlertDefinition.name: vSphere High Availability (HA) failover resources are insufficient

AlertDefinition.description: Datastore contains virtual machines that are unexpectedly using significant amount of disk I/O
AlertDefinition.name: Datastore has unexpected high disk I/O workload

AlertDefinition.description: More than 5% of virtual machines in the cluster have memory compression, ballooning, or swapping, indicating memory contention
AlertDefinition.name: More than 5% of virtual machines in the cluster have memory contention due to memory compression, ballooning, or swapping

AlertDefinition.description: Host in a cluster that does not have fully-automated DRS enabled has memory contention. Half or fewer of the virtual machines are overloading the host
AlertDefinition.name: Host in a cluster that does not have fully-automated DRS enabled has memory contention caused by less than half of the virtual machines

AlertDefinition.description: A cluster with DRS enabled and set to fully-automated has memory contention. Half or fewer of the virtual machines are overloading the cluster
AlertDefinition.name: Fully-automated DRS-enabled cluster has memory contention caused by less than half of the virtual machines

AlertDefinition.description:
The failover does not succeed because a problem occurs when vSphere HA attempts to restart the virtual machine. This problem can occur if another operation that is running on the same virtual machine prevents the virtual machine from being registered or reconfigured. This problem can also occur if the virtual machine is still powered on or the virtual machine configuration file is corrupt.
The symptom in the alert includes information about the error that occurred when vSphere HA attempted the failover. vSphere HA retries the failover on another host unless the maximum number of failover attempts is exceeded. Typically, the retry succeeds.
AlertDefinition.name: vSphere HA cannot perform a failover operation for the virtual machine

AlertDefinition.description: One or more battery sensors on the host are reporting problems. Specific details should be available in the symptom details. For more information, check the Hardware Status of the host in vSphere Client.
AlertDefinition.name: Battery sensors are reporting problems

AlertDefinition.description: Virtual machine has memory contention due to swap wait and high disk read latency
AlertDefinition.name: Virtual machine has memory contention caused by swap wait and high disk read latency

AlertDefinition.description: One or more hardware sensors on the host are reporting problems. The name of the hardware sensor, the group to which the hardware sensor belongs, and the possible cause of the problem should appear in the symptom details. For more information, check the Hardware Status of the host in vSphere Client.
AlertDefinition.name: Hardware sensors are reporting problems

AlertDefinition.description: ESXi host has detected a link status down on a physical NIC.
AlertDefinition.name: ESXi host has detected a link status down on a physical NIC

AlertDefinition.description: A cluster with DRS enabled and set to fully-automated has memory contention caused by overpopulation of virtual machines. More than half of the virtual machines are overloading the cluster
AlertDefinition.name: Fully-automated DRS-enabled cluster has memory contention caused by more than half of the virtual machines

AlertDefinition.description: One or more guest file systems of the virtual machine are running out of disk space. Check the symptom details to identify the affected guest file system
AlertDefinition.name: One or more virtual machine guest file systems are running out of disk space

SymptomDefinition.name: At least one host in the cluster has critically high memory "demand" workload
Battery sensor health state degraded

Condition.eventMsg: Hardware sensor health state degraded. Sensor information: Type = battery,.*

SymptomDefinition.name: Host memory workload at Immediate level
Host(s) lost redundancy to storage device(s)
VMsafe CPU/memory APIs - port number configured (5.5 Hardening Guide)
Datastore Time Remaining is moderately low
Host CPU demand at Immediate level
Cluster CPU "demand" workload at warning level
Virtual machine is orphaned
RP 1 - VM.disable-unexposed-features-unity - Unity feature is enabled
At least one host in the cluster has critically high CPU "demand" workload
Custom Datacenter Time Remaining is starting to get low
Virtual machine memory contention is at warning level
Virtual machine disk I/O workload at Immediate level
Hardware sensor health is yellow
Lost connection to NFS server
Storage device has been turned off administratively
RP 1 - VM.disable-unexposed-features-toporequest - Toprequest feature is enabled (5.5/6.0 Hardening Guide)
Disk command latency at Warning level
Non-compliant max VM log file count (5.5 Hardening Guide)
RP 1,2,3 - ESXi.enable-chap-auth - Bidirectional CHAP is not enabled, authentication for iSCSI traffic
Non-compliant max VM log file size (5.5 Hardening Guide)
Processor sensor health state degraded

Condition.eventMsg: Hardware sensor health state degraded. Sensor information: Type = processor,.*

SymptomDefinition.name: Network traffic is blocked for one or more ports
Host System Time Remaining is moderately low

Recommendation.Description: The PCIe error is recoverable, but system behavior is dependent on how the error is handed by the OEM vendor's firmware. Contact the vendor for assistance.
Because recoverable errors are vendor specific, contact the vendor for assistance.
Reduce the amount of network traffic being generated by virtual machines by moving some of them to a host with lower network traffic
Check and replace the PCIe device identified in the alert as the cause of the problem. Contact the vendor for assistance.
Add more hosts to cluster.
Add more memory for this virtual machine
Check the Fault page under Analysis tab for this object for more details
Review the load balancing policy in the Port Group and the vSwitch
Replace the faulty memory or contact the vendor for assistance.
Check the applications running on the virtual machines in the cluster to determine whether high CPU workload is an expected behavior.
Upgrade the host or use a host that has larger memory capacity.
Delete any unused templates on the datastore.
Use vMotion to migrate this virtual machine to a different host or cluster
Ensure that VMware Tools is running in the virtual machine.
Add memory reservations to this virtual machine to prevent ballooning and swapping.

If the error information reports that a file is locked, the virtual machine might be powered on on a host that the vSphere HA master agent can no longer monitor by using the management network or heartbeat datastores.
Use Storage vMotion to migrate this virtual machine to a different datastore with higher IOPS
Check the applications running on the virtual machines in the cluster to determine whether high memory workload is an expected behavior.

Check your vCenter Server instance for performance problems, and ensure that all services are running normally. If the vCenter Server instance is overloaded, it might not be able to respond in the required interval of 5 minutes. To diagnose performance problems, review other alerts on the vCenter Adapter instance object or on the virtual machine running the vCenter Server instance.

Change or replace the hardware, if necessary. Contact the hardware vendor for assistance. After the problem is resolved, the alert will be canceled when the sensor that reported the problem indicates that the problem no longer exists.
Use Storage vMotion to migrate some virtual machines to a different datastore
Review the symptoms listed and remove the number of vCPUs from the virtual machine as recommended by the symptom.
The virtual machine might have been powered on by a user on a host outside of the cluster. If any hosts are declared offline, determine whether a networking or storage problem caused the situation.
Add the host to a fully-automated-DRS cluster to allow vSphere to move virtual machines as needed when resources are available on other hosts in the cluster.

To determine the actual failure or to eliminate possible problems, check the status of the vmnic in vSphere Client or from the ESX service console:
- To check the status in vSphere Client, select the ESX host, click Configuration, and click Networking. The vmnics currently assigned to virtual switches appear in the diagrams. If a vmnic displays a red X, that link is currently down.
- From the service console, run the command:esxcfg-nics -l
The output that appears is similar to the following:
Name PCI Driver Link Speed Duplex Description
------------------------------------------------------------------
vmnic0 04:04.00 tg3 Up 1000Mbps Full Broadcom BCM5780 Gigabit Ethernet
vmnic1 04:04.01 tg3 Up 1000Mbps Full Broadcom BCM5780 Gigabit Ethernet

The Link column shows the status of the link between the network adapter and the physical switch. The status can be either Up or Down. If some network adapters are up and others are down, you might need to verify that the adapters are connected to the intended physical switch ports. To verify the connections, bring down each ESX host port on the physical switch, run the "esxcfg-nics -l" command, and observe the affected vmnics.

Verify that the vmnic identified in the alert is still connected to the switch and configured properly:
- Make sure that the network cable is still connected to the switch and to the host.
- Make sure that the switch is connected to the system, is still functioning properly, and has not been inadvertently misconfigured. For more information, see the switch documentation.
- Check for activity between the physical switch and the vmnic. You can check activity by performing a network trace or observing activity LEDs.
- Check for network port settings on the physical switch.

To reconfigure the service console IP address if the affected vmnic is associated with a service console, see VMware KB 1000258.

If the problem is caused by your hardware, contact your hardware vendor for replacement hardware.

To resolve this problem, use similar CPU and memory reservations for all virtual machines in the cluster. If this solution is not possible, consider using a different vSphere HA admission control policy, such as reserving a percentage of cluster resource for failover. Alternatively, you can use advanced options to specify a cap for the slot size. For more information, see the vSphere Availability Guide. Hosts that have vSphere HA agent errors are not good candidates for providing failover capacity in the cluster and their resources are not considered for vSphere HA admission control purposes. If many hosts have a vSphere HA agent error, vCenter Server generates this event leading to the fault. To resolve vSphere HA agent errors, check the event logs for the hosts to determine the cause of the errors. After you resolve any configuration problems, reconfigure vSphere HA on the affected hosts or on the cluster.
Check the applications running on the virtual machines placed on the datastore to determine whether high disk I/O workload is an expected behavior.
Increase or remove the CPU limits on this virtual machine
Move this virtual machine to a different host or cluster.
Configure at least one management network on the host that is also available on all other hosts in the vSphere HA cluster. Refer to the vSphere Availability guide for details.
For advanced troubleshooting information, see VMware KB 1003967.
Ensure the MTU configuration on the physical switch and the Distributed Switch are consistent
Use vMotion to migrate some virtual machines off the host or Cluster

Network latency between a node running the vCenter Adapter and the vCenter Server instance can impact query time latency. Ensure that the network latency between the node and the vCenter Server instance is not impacting the overall performance of data collection. Remote collectors can help to improve data collection performance and reliability in high-latency network environments. If network latency exceeds 100ms, deploy a remote collector as close as possible to the vCenter Server instance from which data is being collected.
Determine whether the other hosts that use the same NFS mount are experiencing the same problem, then check the NFS server status and share points.

Verify that VMware Tools is installed and running, and that the balloon driver is enabled in the guest. Memory ballooning helps the host reclaim unused memory from the guest more effectively, and might avoid swapping.

Resolve the networking problem that is preventing the host from pinging its isolation addresses and communicating with other hosts. Verify that the management networks that vSphere HA uses include redundancy. With redundancy, vSphere HA can communicate over more than one path, which reduces the chance of a host becoming isolated.
Bring any failed hosts online or resolve a network partition, if one exists.
Check whether the virtual machine has an ISO file attached to its CD/DVD drive, and whether the file was deleted or moved. If so, follow the instructions in VMware KB 1015791 to disconnect the ISO.
Clear the IPMI System Event log file and reset the sensors. See VMware KB 1033725 for details.
If virtual machine CPU reservation is set, decrease the CPU reservation configuration.
Delete unused snapshots of virtual machines from datastore
Check the security policy on the port groups as well as any ACL rule configuration
Enable fully-automated DRS in the cluster to allow vSphere to move virtual machines as needed when resources are available on other hosts in the cluster.
Verify that there is physical connectivity for the NICs on the host. Verify the admin status on the port
If you added this host to a different vCenter, remove it from the current vCenter.
The actions to take to resolve the problems depend on the specific problem that caused the fault. Review the issue details and check the vSphere documentation.

Add a new virtual hard disk or expand the existing disk of the virtual machine. You must first remove all snapshots before expanding an existing disk. After completing this, use a guest OS specific procedure to expand the file system on the new or expanded disk.
Check the networking configuration to verify that the ESX host can connect to the NFS server.
Turn on DRS on the cluster. Manually approve the DRS recommendations or set DRS to fully automated.
Right-size large virtual machines as it helps in reducing overall resource contention. Use the Reclaimable Capacity feature within vRealize Operations for recommended rightsizing of VMs.
Use vMotion to migrate some virtual machines with high memory workload to other hosts that have available memory capacity.

Ask the administrator about the device state. If the device is turned on, the fault will be resolved and the alert will be canceled. If SCSI devices are detached or permanently removed, you must manually cancel the alert.
Use vMotion to migrate some virtual machines with high CPU workload to other hosts that have available CPU capacity.

If you deleted the virtual machine outside of vCenter Server, then connect to the vCenter Server using vSphere Client or vSphere Web Client and remove the virtual machine from the inventory. Otherwise, refer to VMware KB 1003742 for troubleshooting steps for recovering the invalid or orphaned virtual machine under various conditions.
Increase IOPS for the datastores connected to the virtual machine

If the VMware tools version is too new, downgrade it to a supported version. Otherwise, upgrade VMware Tools to the latest version. Select this virtual machine in the vSphere Client or Web Client, then right-click and select "Upgrade VMware Tools".
If virtual machine memory reservation is set, decrease the memory reservation configuration.
Set memory reservations for the virtual machine to prevent its memory from being swapped.
If DRS is in manual mode,look for pending recommendations and approve the recommendations so that vSphere HA failover can proceed.
Ensure the teaming configuration on the physical switch and the Distributed Switch are consistent
Add more hosts to the cluster to increase memory capacity

If the error information reports that the virtual machine is in an invalid state, an in-progress operation might be preventing access to the virtual machine files. Determine whether any operations are in progress, such as a clone operation that is taking a long time to complete.

To reduce the high co-stop values and improve virtual machine performance, consolidate any snapshots into the main virtual disk. Open the vSphere Client, select the virtual machine, then right-click, and select 'Snapshot -> Consolidate'.

After consolidation, the co-stop value is reduced or eliminated and virtual machine performance improves. If performance does not improve enough, continue to research other potential virtual machine performance issues.
See VMware KB 2000058.
You can also try to power on the virtual machine and investigate any returned errors.
Increase IOPS for the datastore.
Check whether you have enabled Storage IO Control on the datastores connected to the virtual machine
Fix the vSphere Security Configuration Guide Rules Violations according to the recommendations available at vSphere Security Configuration Guide.
If the virtual machine has multiple snapshots, delete the older snapshots
Set DRS to fully automated if it is not. If it is already fully automated, make DRS more aggressive.

To determine the actual failure or to eliminate possible problems, first connect to ESX through SSH or the console:
1) Identify the available uplinks with the following command:
esxcfg-nics -l
2) Remove the reported vmnic from the port groups with the following command:
esxcfg-vswitch -U [affected vmnic] affected vSwitch
3) Link available uplinks to the affected port groups with the following command:
esxcfg-vswitch -L [available vmnic] affected vSwitch

Next, check the status of the vmnic in vSphere Client or the ESX service console:
- In vSphere Client, select the ESX host, click Configuration, and click Networking.
The vmnics currently assigned to virtual switches appear in the diagrams. If a vmnic displays a red X, that link is currently unavailable.
- From the service console, run the following command:
esxcfg-nics -l
The output that appears is similar to the following example:
Name PCI Driver Link Speed Duplex Description
------------------------------------------------------------------
vmnic0 04:04.00 tg3 Up 1000Mbps Full Broadcom BCM5780 Gigabit Ethernet
vmnic1 04:04.01 tg3 Up 1000Mbps Full Broadcom BCM5780 Gigabit Ethernet

The Link column shows the status of the link between the network adapter and the physical switch. The status can be either Up or Down. If some network adapters are up and others are down, you might need to verify that the adapters are connected to the intended physical switch ports. To verify the connections, shut down each ESX host port on the physical switch, run the "esxcfg-nics -l" command, and observe the affected vmnics.

Verify that the vmnic identified in the alert is still connected to the switch and configured properly:
- Make sure that the network cable is still connected to the switch and to the host.
- Make sure that the switch is connected to the system, is still functioning properly, and was not inadvertently misconfigured. (See the switch documentation.)
- Perform a network trace or observe activity LEDs to check for activity between the physical switch and the vmnic.
- Check for network port settings on the physical switch.
If the problem is caused by hardware, contact your hardware vendor for a hardware replacement.
Increase the datastore I/O capacity for the connected datastores to reduce CPU I/O wait on the virtual machine.
Use vMotion to migrate some virtual machines to a different cluster if possible.
Check the applications running on the virtual machine to determine whether high disk I/O workload is an expected behavior.
Add an additional NIC to the host
Verify that the NFS server is running.
Adjust the MTU configuration on the host to match the physical switch. Change the MTU configuration on the physical switch

Reduce the number of snapshots by consolidating the snapshots into 1 snapshot. Use the vSphere Client to perform this operation. Select the virtual machine, then right-click, and select 'Snapshot -> Consolidate'.

Find the computer that has the duplicate IP address and reconfigure it to have a different IP address. This fault will be cleared and the alert canceled when the underlying problem is resolved and the vSphere HA master agent is able to connect to the HA agent on the host.

NOTE: You can use the Duplicate IP warning in the /var/log/vmkernel log file on an ESX host or the /var/log/messages log file on an ESXi host to identify the computer that has the duplicate IP address.

The storage device path, for example, vmhba35:C1:T0:L7, contains several potential failure points:
Path Element | Failure Point
---------------------------------------
vmhba35 | HBA (Host Bus Adapter)
C1 | Channel
T0 | Target (storage processor port)
L7 | LUN (Logical Unit Number or Disk Unit)

Use the following guidance to determine the cause of the failure or to eliminate possible problems.

Identify the available storage paths to the reported storage device by running the command esxcfg-mpath - l. For more information, see VMware KB 1003973.

Verify that a rescan does not restore visibility to the targets. For information about using the command-line interface and VMware vSphere Client to rescan the storage device, see VMware KB 1003988.

Determine whether the connectivity issue is with the iSCSI storage or the fiber storage. Troubleshoot the connectivity to the iSCSI storage by using the software initiator:
1) Check whether a ping to the storage array fails from ESX. For more information, see VMware KB 1003486.
2) Check whether a vmkping to each network portal of the storage array fails. For more information, see VMware KB 1003728.
3) Check that the initiator is registered on the array. For more information, contact your storage vendor.
4) Check that the following physical hardware is functioning correctly: Ethernet switch, Ethernet cables between the switch and the ESX host, and Ethernet cables between the switch and the storage array.

To troubleshoot the connectivity to the fiber-attached storage, check the fiber switch. The fiber switch zoning configuration permits the ESX host to see the storage array. If you require assistance, contact your switch vendor. The fiber switch propagates RSCN messages to the ESX hosts. For more information about configuring the fiber switch, see VMware KB 1002301.

Finally, check the following physical hardware: the storage processors on the array, the fiber switch and the Gigabit Interface Converter (GBIC) units in the switch, the fiber cables between the fiber switch and the array, and the array itself.

You must rescan after making changes to make sure that the targets are detected. If storage connectivity is restored for all of the affected host and storage device combinations, the fault is cleared and the alert canceled. If storage connectivity for the devices indicated is caused by a permanent loss or change, you must cancel the fault alert as a workaround. The alert will be canceled automatically after that.
Increase the memory limit for the virtual machine so that it matches the recommended memory size. Alternatively, remove memory limit for the virtual machine.
Use the workload balance feature in vRealize Operations to migrate one or more virtual machines to a different cluster.

ESXi disables the device to avoid the link flapping state. You might need to replace the physical NIC. The alert will be canceled when the NIC is repaired and functioning. If you replace the physical NIC, you might need to manually cancel the alert.
If the host has 1 CPU, upgrade the host or use a host that has larger CPU capacity.
Refer to Troubleshooting vSphere HA Host States section of vSphere documentation for further troubleshooting.
Keep HA enabled when Fault Tolerance (FT) is required to protect virtual machines.

Change the Distributed Switch configuration to match the host. Identify the Distributed Switch properties that are out of sync. If these properties were changed locally on the host in order to maintain connectivity, update the Distributed Switch configuration in vCenter. Otherwise, re-apply the vCenter configuration to the host
Make sure that you can reach the NFS server by logging into the service console and using vmkping to ping the NFS server: "vmkping [nfs server]".

Click "Open Host in vSphere Web Client" in the Actions menu at the top of Alert details page to connect to the vCenter managing this host and manually reconnect the host to vCenter Server. After the connection to the host is restored by vCenter Server, the alert will be canceled.
Enable the secondary virtual machine indicated in the alert.
Manually power on the virtual machine.
Replace the physical adapter or reset the physical switch. The alert will be canceled when connectivity is restored to the dvPort.
If the time period of maintenance window is expected, you can cancel this alert. Otherwise, investigate further and take the host out of maintenance mode.
Verify that at least two NICs on each host is connected to the Distributed Switch
Check if the packet drops are due to high CPU resource utilization or uplink bandwidth utilization. Use vMotion to migrate the virtual machine that the port is attached to to a different host.
Add more hosts to the cluster to increase CPU capacity.
Ensure the VLAN configuration on the physical switch and the Distributed Port Groups are consistent
Check the migration threshold in the DRS settings for the cluster. Change it to a more aggressive level to enable DRS to balance the cluster workloads.

Resolve the networking problem that prevents the hosts from communicating through the management network. See VMware KB 2012649 if the network partition happened due to SSL certificate thumbprint mismatch. See VMware KB 2004429 for general HA troubleshooting guidance.
